moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Nc6: This N should not be moved there, IMO... not a great deal, but it's much easier to play without c5 from black.
moves.3. Nf3 e6: ...blocking his own lsb. Good for me.
moves.4. Nbd2 f5: This implies I have to play g4 at some point in order to break in.
moves.5. e3 Nf6 6. h3 Be7: Still passive... but my edge is already in the air.
moves.8. Bd3 Bd7 9. Rg1: This is the first "surprise" for him. Not going for castling.
moves.10. g4 fxg4 11. hxg4 Be8: Finally taking seriously the threates I am creating.
moves.12. Qc2 g6 13. Ng5: ...aiming to the weak e6, but also eyeing a sac in h7 in the future.
moves.13... Qd7 14. Ndf3 b5: Too slow, too late. Now castling queenside is not the priority.
moves.15... Nxe5 16. dxe5 Ne4: ...here, I cannot castle because my N is threatened. I thought for a while about Nxh7, KxN, BxN, dxB, Qxe4, threatening Ra8, and Qh1+... but I wasn't sure. Also Rh1+, Kg8 (otherwise Bh6+ wins the exchange), and then trying to sum my Q and the other R into the attack after Ke2. Well, too long a sequence for a blitz game for me. Probably I missed some chance here.
moves.17. Nxe4 dxe4 18. Bxe4 Rd8: ...but now I can't break into his king's guard so easily. So...
moves.19. Rd1 Qxd1+ 20. Qxd1 Rxd1+ 21. Kxd1: ...and we enter an endgame, (sort of), with 4 bishops, a pawn and a cramped R for him, which I try to exploit.
moves.22. Ke2: ...but this defends my f2 pawn. You'll see why.
moves.22... Kg7: He saw it, and tried to activate his K, guarding h6.
moves.24. Bh6 Rf7 25. f4: ...his dsb is almost blocked in. The only way to free his R is Bd8.
moves.25... c4: ...or this, but on c5, his dsb has not much perspectives. Now it's time for a little tactic.
moves.28... Kh8 29. Bxf7 Bxf7: ...here Rg1 threatens Rg7, winning one of the two bishops. I didn't see it. Moreover, I blundered.
moves.30. Rd1: ?? Bh5+ and he gets his quality back.
moves.30... Be6: ...but he doesn't see it. Bad for both of us.
moves.31. Kf3: Now I can improve my K.
moves.31... Kg8: Kind of a mistake. It loses h7.
moves.35. Kf4 Be4 36. Bg7: I plan Bf6, and if he takes, my pawn will promote on dark square.
moves.36... Bc5 37. Rh8+ Kd7: Useless check, since I can't play Ra8 afterwards.
moves.38. Rh6: Trying another plan to advance my pawn. Even if I have a strong edge, it's a kind of edge that I can easily throw away.
moves.38... a5 39. e6+ Ke7 40. Bd4: He can't exchange, or my pawns will become monsters.
moves.42... a4 43. Ke5: ...My K helps. I have to choose: keep an eye on e3, or going for a promotion.
moves.43... Bxe3 44. Rh7+ Ke8 45. e7 Bf2: ...looking for a skewer with Bg3+. Here, Ke6 and the game was over, but nobody's perfect!
moves.47. Kf6: He can't prevent me from promotion!
moves.47... f4: If I play Kf7, Bd5+ or BxR and I win all the same. But more precise, IMO, was...
moves.48. Rh8: My opp. resigned. Wow, almost a high win!

gameName: How can HE TOO miss it!
